content.question: Solid Mass of Water <math alttext="delta T sub water" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>T</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>w</mi><mi>a</mi><mi>t</mi><mi>e</mi><mi>r</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1.0 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="2000.0 grams" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2000.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="positive 2.1 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mn>2.1</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> A sample of a solid organic compound is completely combusted in a calorimeter. The heat generated by combustion is transferred to the water, causing the temperature of the water to increase. Based on the data in the table above, which of the following is the best estimate of the heat of combustion, <math alttext="delta H sub combustion" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>o</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, of the organic solid? skill.text: 5.F: Calculate, estimate, or predict an unknown quantity from known quantities by selecting and following a logical computational pathway and attending to precision (e.g., performing dimensional analysis and attending to significant figures).
